keyTakeAways: Indigenous human knowledge, such as observing natural signs (rainfall, animal behavior, sound patterns), is still widely used and effective in predicting and mitigating glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs) in Pakistan’s mountain regions.

Despite significant investments in early warning systems (EWS), including a $37 million GLOF-II project, communities in Gilgit-Baltistan lack trust in the systems due to malfunctioning equipment, poor communication, and lack of community involvement.

In multiple incidents, villagers—especially shepherds—have successfully saved lives using traditional alert methods (e.g., gunfire signals, fire signals), demonstrating that human-based, locally embedded knowledge remains more reliable and accessible than technology in some cases.
Pakistan is one of the top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions, with temperature increases since the 1950s being twice the global average.
The failure of official EWS systems has led to public skepticism, with critics accusing officials of falsely claiming success and failing to address operational gaps or community concerns.

The government’s recognition of heroic actions by individuals like Wasiyat Khan, with financial rewards, underscores the value placed on community-based resilience in the absence of functional institutional systems.

namedEntities.name: Wasiyat Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Roshan Valley, Ghizer, who survived a glacial lake outburst flood and alerted villagers using traditional methods, playing a key role in saving lives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He exemplifies how Indigenous knowledge and personal initiative are critical in real-time disaster response when technology fails.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Hussain
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd in Skardu Valley, Gilgit-Baltistan, who experienced and responded to a flash flood using traditional signals, including gunfire.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His experience illustrates the effectiveness of ancestral knowledge systems in predicting and alerting communities during floods.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, particularly Gilgit-Baltistan, Indigenous knowledge—such as observing natural signs like thunder, animal behavior, and unusual sounds—is being used to predict and prevent deadly glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). Despite government investments in expensive early warning systems (EWS), such as the $37 million GLOF-II project, communities lack trust due to equipment failures, lack of community involvement, and poor follow-up. In several incidents, shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain have successfully saved lives by using traditional alert methods, such as gunfire signals, demonstrating that human-based knowledge remains both accessible and effective. The article underscores Pakistan’s status as one of the most climate-vulnerable nations, with rising temperatures and reduced snowfall accelerating glacier melt. It concludes that while technology plays a role, true resilience depends on trust, community inclusion, and the integration of local wisdom into disaster response frameworks.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
